Dear Rebecca Stowell:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. No
substantial violations were found.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Samantha Way at 517-24-9743.
Sincerely,
Brittany Cowans, Licensing Consultant

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
Special Investigation #: 2025SIC0000508
Special Investigation Intake Date: March 27, 2025
License #: CO330201191
Licensee Group Organization: 30th Judicial Circuit Court, Family Division
Licensee Designee: Annette Ellison
Chief Administrator: Rebecca Stowell
Agency Name: INGHAM COUNTY YOUTH CENTER
Agency Address: 700 E JOLLY RD
LANSING, MI 48910-6832
License Status: Inspected
License Expiration Date: 11/25/2026
Capacity: 24
II. METHODOLOGY

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Title Programs and services
Rule Code & COF Rule 400.10149
Section (2) A facility shall provide or make available the following minimum
Description programs and services to residents:
(c) Counseling.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A did not receive counseling for three days.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed over the phone on 5/7/2025. The
complainant did not provide additional information.
Youth A was interviewed at Eaton County Youth Center with
MDHHS Worker on 3/28/2025. Youth A was interviewed at Eaton
County Youth Center, where he has been for 9 days. He was
transferred from Ingham County Youth Center due to a fight
between him and another youth. He stated while placed at Ingham
County Youth Center, he was on lockdown from 3/7/2025 –
3/10/2025, and then placed on a modified, phase 4 program from
3/10/2025 until his transfer to Eaton on 3/18/2025. On the
modified program, youth receive two hours outside of their room
and the rest of time is in lockdown. He stated youth are provided
with a big folder and books that have four phases to complete
before lockdown can be lifted. He also stated youth can read while
on lockdown and mealtimes are in the room. He stated staff
would not let him complete counseling while he was in lockdown,
however, he did receive counseling and group therapy before he
was put on the modified program.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed at the facility with MDHHS
Worker on 3/28/2025 and over the phone on 6/4/2025.
Supervisor 1 stated on 3/7/2025, Youth A and two other youths
physically assaulted another youth. The two other youths were
sent to jail due to the severity of the assault and their age. Due to
Youth’s A age, he could not go to jail. He stated Youth A was on
lockdown from 3/7/2025 – 3/10/2025 and then from 3/10/2025 –
3/18/2025, Youth A entered the phase four modification program.
The youth do schoolwork in the dayroom and come out for an
2

hour for activities in the afternoon. The youth also eat in their
room. There are levels to each phase. He reported Youth A was
never denied counseling services. Youth A did meet with
Therapist 1, but he did not recall the dates those occurred.
Supervisor 1 did speak to Youth’s A mother on 3/9/2025 and
explained the lockdown and modification program protocol.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed with MDHHS Worker on
3/28/2025 and over the phone on 6/4/2025. Supervisor 2 stated
this allegation is not true. Youth A met with his therapist on 3/6/25
and on 3/11/2025. He is unsure if Youth A met with Therapist 1 or
Therapist 2. He also met with his community mental health and
wraparound worker on 3/13/2025.
Chief Administrator was interviewed over the phone with
MDHHS Worker on 4/21/2025 and 6/4/2025. Chief Administrator
stated this allegation is not true, as Youth A did meet with
Therapist 1, but she could not recall the dates this occurred. She
also spoke to Youth A’s Mother on 3/10/2025 about her concerns
regarding why Youth A was on lockdown.
Therapist 1 was interviewed over the phone on 5/20/2025.
Therapist stated she went to Ingham County Youth Center to visit
Youth A on 3/10/2025, however, she was turned away due to
Youth A being on lockdown for his involvement of assault to
another youth at Ingham County Youth Center that occurred on
3/7/2025. She stated she called Ingham County Youth Center on
3/18/2025 to inquire if she could visit Youth A, however, she was
then told Youth A had transferred to Eaton County Youth Center.
Juvenile County Officer (JCO) was contacted via email on
5/20/2025. JCO stated she tried to meet with Youth A at Ingham
County Youth Center on 3/7/2025, however, she was unable as
Youth A had just assaulted another youth. She met with Youth A
on 3/13/2025 at 2:00pm for his Wraparound meeting with
Community Mental Health. JCO also met with Youth A in the
morning of 3/18/2025, around 7:50am, prior to him being
transferred to Eaton County Youth Center.
Therapist 2 was contacted via email on 6/5/2025. Therapist 2
stated he met with Youth A on 3/6/2025 and 3/11/2025 at Ingham
County Youth Center. In their sessions they discuss coping
strategies for anxiety, depression and strategies to work towards
avoiding future legal entanglement.
3

Documentation Received:
• Unusual Incident Report dated 3/7/2025: Staff witnessed
Youth A and two other youth physically assault another
youth. Youth A kicked the youth while he was on the floor
and slapped him multiple times in his face. The youth’s face
was bloody, and his left eye was swollen shut.
• Mental Health Care Program Policy: Policy states that all
juveniles are provided with access to mental health
services designed to provide psychological diagnosis of
detained juveniles.
• Youth A Behavior Modification Program dated for 3/10/25:
o Youth A is to remain separate from other youths
meaning he will not participate in school, group,
gym, and/or meals conducted in a group setting at
all during this place.
o Youth A is required to transition to and from his room
when he is instructed by staff.
o Youth A will come out of his room to complete
planned program expectations for 1 hour then return
back to his room for 1 hour. The amount of
opportunities for the modified program to be out will
be determined by building dynamics and may vary
from day to day and shift to shift.
o Youth A will be provided CBT/RBT material to
complete. Assignments will be geared towards
behavior change, anger and aggression and
decision making on the PM shift and weekends.
o Youth A will spend some of his time in the gym if
staffing permits.
o Shower time will be determined by the shift
supervisor and may vary from shift to shift. All
showers will take place in the Intake shower.
o Youth A will not be earning points and is not eligible
for Plus Party food.
o Youth A may receive tokens as a positive
reinforcement for his behavior deemed appropriate
by staff and supervisors but cannot participate in
purchasing items from the store during this phase.
o Youth A will be given an opportunity to evaluate his
week on Monday so this can be presented to the
Managers Meeting on Wednesday afternoon.
o If Youth A refuses to comply with expectations of his
modified program, has any negative talk indicating
defiance, he will forfeit his day. His programming will
end at that moment for the day, he will not be
afforded another opportunity to program on this day.
4

o If youth are making threats to staff or residents, they
would not be allowed out of their rooms. Food would
be provided to them in their rooms, and they would
not be allowed out of their room for showers. None
of the staff would deny a shower unless it was
unsafe.
• Email communication between Chief Administrator and
Juvenile Court Officer dated 6/5/2025: JCO stated that
herself, Youth A, Therapist 1, Youth’s A Mother and
wraparound coordinator, participated in a zoom meeting on
3/13/2025.
• Email communication between Chief Administrator and
Therapist 2 dated 3/6/2025 and 3/11/2025: Therapist 2
provided therapy notes for his session with Youth A on
3/6/2025 and 3/11/2025.
Analysis The facility was found in compliance as per interviews with staff
and documentation reviewed, Youth A did receive counseling
services in alignment with agency policy.
Technical Assistance:
Technical assistance was provided in regards to providing details
within the counseling policy such as frequency of services and
implementation of services when youth are in lockdown.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Title Personal hygiene
Rule Code & COF Rule 400.10163
Section A facility shall arrange for each resident to maintain or receive
Description personal care, hygiene, and grooming appropriate for the
resident's age, sex, race, cultural background, and health needs.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A was not allowed to shower for three days.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed over the phone on 5/7/2025. The
complainant did not provide additional information.
Youth A was interviewed with MDHHS Worker on 3/28/2025.
Youth A stated staff did not let him shower for 4-5 days. He stated
staff did not offer him a shower and when he asked Staff 1 for a
shower, Staff 1 said, “no”. Youth A could not recall the dates he
wasn’t offered as shower. He started that he was able to shower
the rest of his time at Ingham County on the modified program.
5

Supervisor 1 was interviewed with MDHHS Worker on
3/28/2025. Supervisor 1 stated the facility does not deny any
youth use of a shower. He stated that a staff member or
supervisor will take a youth to shower in the afternoon. Youth A
was never denied a shower for three days.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed with MDHHS Worker on
3/28/2025. Supervisor 2 stated staff do not deny youth the use of
a shower. He reported that Youth A may have refused a shower
but did not recall the date. Youth A was offered showers and was
never refused a shower for three days. He explained all youth are
offered a shower every day. Supervisor 2 stated that this
allegation was not true.
Staff 1 was called with MDHHS Worker on 4/21/2025. Message
was left to return contact. As of the date of this report, contact had
not been returned.
Chief Administrator was interviewed with MDHHS Worker
over the phone on 4/21/2025. Chief Administrator stated this
allegation is not true. Youth A had regular interaction and
communication with staff. Chief Administrator reported staff would
never leave a youth without a shower and all youths are offered a
shower throughout the day. She stated youth are offered a shower
every day, however, Youth A did miss a shower one day due to
him sleeping. However, he was offered a shower at a later time.
Documentation Received:
• Youth A’s Daily Info/Point Sheet:
o 3/4/2025: Received shower.
o 3/5/2025: Received shower.
o 3/6/25: Received shower.
o 3/7/2025: Unable to shower due to going on
lockdown. Staff did not document if Youth A received
a shower at a later time.
o 3/8/25: Not documented if Youth A received a
shower.
o 3/9/2025: Received shower.
o 3/10/2025: Sleeping.
o 3/11/2025: Received shower.
o 3/12/2025: Threatened violence to another youth
and not allowed to come out due to safety. Unusual
Incident Report for this date states Youth A shouted,
“is that a new intake, I’m going to bust your head
when I come out.” Youth A received a shower the
following day.
6

o 3/13/2025: Received shower.
o 3/14/2025: Received shower.
o 3/15/2025: Received shower.
o 3/16/2025: Received shower.
o 3/17/2025: Refused shower.
o 3/18/2025: Received shower.
• Environmental and Programmatic Rights Policy: States
residents are afforded daily showers. This expectation
applies to all residents despite their status – regular
programming, re-entry, or Administrative Room
Confinement. If the resident is an acting out person, staff
will assist with getting the resident back under control
emotionally and behaviorally to get a resident out for a
shower. If a resident refuses a shower staff will note that on
the point sheet or Room confinement sheet. If the resident
doesn’t get a shower for some reason (for example - they
were acting out) staff will either offer the shower later in the
shift or the overnight shift if they are still awake or the
following morning.
• Updated Daily Point Sheet: Includes new check boxes for
showering: yes, no and refused.
Analysis The facility was found in compliance as per interviews with staff
and documentation received, there was insufficient evidence
found that Youth A did not receive a shower for three days.
Technical Assistance:
Technical assistance provided in ensuring staff are completing
daily documentation of youth showers.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Title Resident nutrition
Rule Code & COF Rule 400.10165
Section (1) A facility shall provide a minimum of 3 nutritious meals daily,
Description unless medically contraindicated and documented.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A was not provided with food for three days.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed over the phone on 5/7/2025. The
complainant did not provide additional information.
Youth A was interviewed with MDHHS Worker on 3/28/2025.
Youth A stated that while on lockdown and in the modification
program, he had breakfast, lunch and dinner in his room. He
stated that any staff member would bring him his meals. He
7

reported he did not have any issues with getting meals and did
receive three meals a day, but sometimes they ran late. He stated
dinner time is at 5pm but they brought him dinner twice at 6pm.
He stated that lunch time is 12:30pm and there was one time he
received it at 1:00pm. There were no issues with breakfast. He
stated one time prior to him being on lockdown, he had half a
burger and three pieces of broccoli for dinner, and he was
supposed to have two burgers.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed with MDHHS Worker on
3/28/2025. Supervisor 1 stated Youth A was provided food for
three days. All youth are provided with three meals and two
snacks a day. He also stated each youth receives the same food
items. He stated the kitchen staff will would not provide half a
burger as the kitchen does not operate by only providing half
meals to youth. He said there is a possibility the kitchen staff may
be running behind a few times, but they will always provide a full
meal to youth.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed with MDHHS Worker on
3/28/2025. Supervisor 2 stated Youth A was provided with all his
meals during the time he was in lockdown and in the modification
program. He stated that the allegation is not true, and Youth A
never went three days without food.
Chief Administrator was interviewed with MDHHS Worker
over the phone on 4/21/2025, 6/4/2025, 6/6/2025 and 6/11/2025.
Chief Administrator (CA) stated Youth A had multiple staff
interacting with him. Chief Administrator reported the facility would
never leave a youth without food and denied Youth A went three
days without a meal. Staff are not required to document a youth’s
meal if they are out of their room with peers. When a youth is on
room restriction, staff would not necessarily document it on a point
sheet, but it would be on a green sheet. The CA stated the agency
made some adjustments to their protocols, including the way staff
are documenting meals on the daily point sheet, and the new
protocol was reviewed by shift supervisors, and again at their all
staff meeting.
Documentation Reviewed:
• Youth A Daily Info Point Sheet:
o 3/4/2025: Ate breakfast, lunch and dinner.
o 3/5/2025: Ate breakfast, snack, lunch and dinner.
o 3/6/2025: Ate breakfast, lunch, snack and dinner.
o 3/7/2025: Ate breakfast and lunch. Sleeping for
dinner.
8

o 3/9/2025: Ate breakfast, lunch and dinner.
o 3/10/2025: Refused breakfast, ate snack, lunch, and
dinner.
o 3/11/2025: Refused breakfast, ate lunch and dinner.
o 3/12/2025: Ate breakfast, snack, lunch and dinner.
o 3/13/2025: Ate breakfast, lunch, dinner and snack.
o 3/16/2025: Ate breakfast, lunch and dinner.
o 3/17/2025: Refused breakfast, ate ++lunch and
dinner.
• Menu Planning and Meal Service: Food Service Policy:
All juveniles shall be provided meals which are nutritionally
adequate, properly prepared and served in the dining hall
except when behavior management requires them to eat in
their room. If youth are confined to their room, youth will
also eat their meals there. Provisions for at least three
melas, two of which are hot meals, at regular intervals
during each 24-hour period, with no more than 14 hours
between the evening meal and breakfast.
• Updated Daily Point Sheet: Includes line items for
breakfast, am snack, lunch, dinner, and pm snack with
checkboxes for: yes, no and refused.
• Daily Roster of Youth and Meal Count Sheets dates
3/4/2025 – 3/18/2025.
Analysis The facility was found in compliance as per interviews with staff
and youth, and documentation received, there was insufficient
evidence found that Youth A did not receive food for three days.
Technical Assistance
Technical Assistance was provided to ensure staff are
documenting meal delivery and meal refusal for each youth on the
youth’s daily point sheet.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
9

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
_______________________________6/6/2025__
Brittany Cowans Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
6/9/2025
